CUMULATIVE CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT FUND
§ 33.001 CREATION OF FUND.
   In accordance with the provisions of I.C. 6-7-1-31.1, there is created a
special fund to be known as the Cumulative Capital Improvement Fund of the city
into which the cigarette taxes allotted to the city by reason of I.C. 6-7-1-
30.1 shall be deposited. The fund shall be a cumulative fund and all of the
moneys deposited into the fund shall be appropriated and used solely for
capital improvements as hereinafter defined and none of the moneys shall revert
to the general fund or be used for any purposes other than capital
improvements.
(1979 Code, § 33.01) (Ord. 2081, passed 6-7-1965)
§ 33.002 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS DEFINED.
   The term CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS means the construction or improvement of any
property owned by the city including but not limited to streets, thoroughfares,
sewers, the retirement of general obligation bonds of the city issued, and the
proceeds used for the purpose of constructing capital improvements. CAPITAL
IMPROVEMENTS shall also mean those uses and purposes set forth in I.C. 36-9-16
and amendments thereto, I.C. 36-9-16.5 and amendments thereto, and I.C. 8-16-
3 and amendments thereto. The term CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT shall not include
salaries of any public officials or employees except those which are directly
chargeable to a capital improvement.
(1979 Code, § 33.02) (Ord. 2081, passed 6-7-1965; Am. Ord. 3673, passed 12-2-
1985)
CUMULATIVE BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT FUND
§ 33.015 NECESSITY OF ESTABLISHING FUND.
   It is of indispensable public necessity to reestablish a Cumulative Building
and Equipment Fund to provide funds for the erection of fire stations, the
erection of additions to and the remodeling of the present buildings used to
house fire fighting equipment, and the purchase of fire fighting equipment and
police radio equipment, or to make the required payments under a lease rental
with option-to-purchase agreement made to acquire this equipment.
(1979 Code, § 33.10) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.016 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   It is determined to reestablish, create, provide, and approve a cumulative
Building and Equipment Fund pursuant to I.C. 36-8-14-1 through I.C. 36-8-14-4.
To provide for the Fund, the Council shall, at the appropriate time, levy a tax
at the rate of $.10 on each $100 of assessed valuation of all taxable property
in the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.11) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.017 EFFECTIVE DATE OF LEVY.
   The tax shall be first levied in 1989, payable in 1990, and annually
thereafter for a total period of 5 years including the levy in 1993, payable in
1994, and expiring thereafter.
(1979 Code, § 33.12) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.018 PUBLIC HEARING; NOTICE.
   (A)   The Council has fixed August 21, 1989, at 7:00 p.m. Eastern Standard
Time as the date and time when the Council shall, in the Council chambers,
consider and determine to levy this tax, and the taxpayers of the city shall
then and there have the right to be heard.
   (B)   The Council directs the City Clerk, after introduction of this levy
and before it is finally enacted, to give 10 days’ notice by publication and by
posting the notice in 3 public places in the city, in accordance with the
provisions of I.C. 5-3-1. The notice shall set forth the text of the levy and
will include the proposed tax rate, the year or years for which it is to be
levied, and its purpose.
(1979 Code, § 33.13) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.019 USE OF FUNDS.
   These tax funds shall not be used for any other purpose than the purpose for
which they were raised.
(1979 Code, § 33.14) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.020 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   As the tax is collected, it shall be deposited in a qualified public
depository or depositories and shall be held in a special fund to be known as
the Cumulative Fire Fighting Equipment Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.15) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
§ 33.021 APPROVAL OF STATE’S BOARD OF TAX COMMISSIONERS.
   After the public hearing, and providing this levy is duly and regularly
passed, the Council shall submit a copy of this levy duly certified by the City
Clerk, to the state’s Board of Tax Commissioners for approval, and shall give
public notice of the submission to the taxpayers of the taxing district by
publication in accordance with I.C. 5-3-1.
(1979 Code, § 33.16) (Ord. 2985, passed 2-6-1978; Am. Ord. 3475, passed 8-15-
1983; Am. Ord. 3935, passed 8-21-1989)
CUMULATIVE BRIDGE FUND
§ 33.035 NECESSITY OF ESTABLISHING FUND.
   It is of indispensable public necessity to reestablish a Cumulative Bridge
Fund to provide for the building, maintenance and repair of bridges and grade
separation in the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.20) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
§ 33.036 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   It is determined to reestablish, provide, and approve a Cumulative Bridge
Fund pursuant to I.C. 8-16-3-1 through I.C. 8-16-3-3. To provide for the Fund,
Council shall, at the appropriate time, levy a tax at a rate of $.10 on each
$100 on all taxable personal and real property within the city. These taxes,
when collected, shall be held in a special fund to be known as the Cumulative
Bridge Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.21) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
§ 33.037 EFFECTIVE DATE OF LEVY.
   The tax shall be first levied in 1978, payable in 1979, and annually
thereafter for a total of 5 years, including the levy in 1982, payable in 1983,
and expiring thereafter as provided in I.C. 8-16-3-3.
(1979 Code, § 33.22) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
§ 33.038 PUBLIC HEARING; NOTICE.
   (A)   The Council has fixed May 1, 1978, at 7:30 p.m. Eastern Standard Time
as the date and time when the Council will, in the Council Chambers, consider
and determine to levy the tax, and the taxpayers of the city shall then and
there have the right to be heard.
   (B)   The Council directs the City Clerk, after introduction of this levy
and before it is finally enacted, to give 10 days’ notice by publication and by
posting the notice in 3 public places in the city in accordance with the
provisions of § 2, Chapter 299, Acts of 1951. The notice shall set forth the
text of this levy which will include the proposed tax rate, the year or years
for which it is to be levied, and its purpose.
(1979 Code, § 33.23) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
§ 33.039 APPROVAL OF STATE’S BOARD OF TAX COMMISSIONERS.
   After the public hearing, and providing this levy is duly and regularly
passed, the Council shall submit a copy of this levy, duly certified by the
City Clerk, to the state’s Board of Tax Commissioners for approval. This levy
shall be in full force and effect upon receipt by the Auditor of Elkhart County
of a certification from the state’s Board of Tax Commissioners approving this
tax levy at any amount not to exceed the levy proposed to be established.
(1979 Code, § 33.24) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
§ 33.040 USE OF FUNDS.
   The tax, when collected, shall not be expended for any purpose other than
the purpose for which it was levied.
(1979 Code, § 33.25) (Ord. 2997, passed 5-1-1978)
JUNK VEHICLE FUND
§ 33.055 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is created the city’s Junk Vehicle Fund which shall be a revolving
fund, and all moneys paid to the city for the cost of removal, storage and
disposal of abandoned vehicles shall be placed in the fund and in no other
place. This fund shall also have added to it any moneys appropriated by the
Council. All money remaining in the fund at the end of each year shall remain
in the fund and not revert to the General Fund. The money in the fund shall be
expended and used only for the purposes enumerated in I.C. 9-22-1. providing
for the disposal of abandoned vehicles by local governments.
(1979 Code, § 33.30) (Ord. 2690, passed 10-15-1973)
CEMETERY FUND
§ 33.065 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
    A separate non-reverting fund titled "Cemetery Fund" shall be created for
the purpose of depositing all moneys, revenues, fees and receipts of every kind
and nature received or derived in any way from sale of lots, burial permits,
care and maintenance of lots or any other source, in or from any cemetery owned
and operated by the city. Such revenues shall be turned over to the Controller
of the city, who shall deposit such funds in the Cemetery Fund. No aprt of
these revenues shall be paid into the General Fund of the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.35) (Ord. 1191, passed 8-1-1930; Am. Ord. 5728, passed 5-6-
2019)
§ 33.066 DISBURSEMENTS.
   (A)   All disbursements for and on account of the cemeteries and additions
thereto, including the salary of the Sexton, and all labor, materials, upkeep
and maintenance expenses shall be disbursed from the fund, and charged thereto,
and no disbursement shall be made from the General Fund of the city.
   (B)   All disbursements from the fund shall be made in the same manner as
other disbursements are made by the city from its General Fund, but the expense
of operation and maintenance of the cemetery properties shall be budgeted by
the Council and shall not exceed in any fiscal year the amount of the budget
allowed by the Council, unless additional appropriation is made, as provided by
law, from the Cemetery Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.36) (Ord. 1191, passed 8-1-1930)
SEWAGE TREATMENT, STORM SEWER AND DISPOSAL PLANT FUND
§ 33.085 NECESSITY OF ESTABLISHING FUND.

cumulative building and sinking fund, hereinafter referred to as Cumulative
Storm Sewer Fund, to provide funds to plan, construct, remodel, repair and
extend storm sewers, and for relief sewers and drains in aid of the sanitary
system and storm sewers of the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.40) (Ord. 2648, passed 5-21-1973)

Storm Sewer Fund pursuant to I.C. 36-9-26.
   (B)   To provide for this fund, this Council shall levy a tax at the rate of
$.10 on each $100 of taxable property in the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.41) (Ord. 2648, passed 5-21-1973)
§ 33.087 EFFECTIVE DATE OF LEVY.

thereafter for a total period of 12 years, including the levy in 1984, payable
in 1985, and expiring as provided in I.C. 36-9-26.
(1979 Code, § 33.42) (Ord. 2648, passed 5-21-1973)

the date and time when the Council in the Council Chambers considered and

   (B)   The Council directs the Clerk of the city, after introduction of §§
33.085 through
33.090 and before they are finally enacted, to give notice by publication in

notice shall set forth the text of §§
33.085 through
33.090 including the proposed tax rate, the year or years for which it is to be

   (A)   After public hearing, and providing §§
33.085 through
33.090 are duly and regularly passed, the Council of the city shall submit a
copy of these sections duly certified by the City Clerk to the state’s Board of
Tax Commissioners for its consideration.
   (B)   Sections
33.085 through
33.090 shall be in full force and effect upon receipt by the Auditor of Elkhart
County, Indiana, of a certification from the state’s Board of Tax Commissioners
approving the tax levy at any amount not to exceed the levy proposed to be
established.
(1979 Code, § 33.44) (Ord. 2648, passed 5-21-1973)
§ 33.090 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   The taxes, when collected, shall be held in a public depository in a special
fund to be known and designated as Sewage Treatment, Storm Sewer and Disposal
Plant Fund, and the fund now known as Cumulative Storm Sewer Fund shall be
entitled Sewage Treatment, Storm Sewer and Disposal Plant Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.45) (Ord. 2648, passed 5-21-1973)
POLICE PENSION FUND

   A Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund is established, and the city
elects to bring itself within the provisions of the Police Pension Fund Act,
being I.C. 36-8-6.
(1979 Code, § 33.50) (Ord. 857, passed 5-6-1920)

FIREMEN’S PENSION FUND
§ 33.115 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is created for the city a Firemen’s Pension Fund and a Board of
Trustees for the control and management of the fund. The Council elects to
establish the Board of Trustees and Firemen’s Pension Fund, being I.C. 36-8-7.
(1979 Code, § 33.55) (Ord. 1274, passed 9-4-1937)
§ 33.116 POWERS OF BOARD OF TRUSTEES.
   The Board of Trustees of the Firemen’s Pension Fund shall have all the
rights and powers provided for by state law.
(1979 Code, § 33.56) (Ord. 1274, passed 9-4-1937)
§ 33.117 ADOPTION OF STATUTE.
   All of the provisions and terms of that Act are adopted as part of this
chapter, as if fully set forth herein at length, and the Board of Trustees of
the Firemen’s Pension Fund shall be managed and controlled as provided for in
the Act. The Board of Trustees shall be in full control and management of the
Fund as provided by state law.
(1979 Code, § 33.57) (Ord. 1274, passed 9-4-1937)
§ 33.118 INTENT AND PURPOSE.
   It is the intent and purpose of §§
33.115 through
33.118 to adopt in full all of the provisions of the act for the control and
management of the Fund as set forth by state law, and to provide funds to the
Board of Trustees for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of these
sections and the state law.
(1979 Code, § 33.58) (Ord. 1274, passed 9-4-1937)
Statutory reference:
   Chapter 31 of the Acts of 1937 is continued as I.C. 36-8-7
SPECIAL PARKING FUND
§ 33.135 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is created a special fund within the Board of Public Works and Safety
of the city into which shall be deposited all license fees and revenues
collected from parking meters, gates and other similar devices used to regulate
the parking of vehicles upon or off any of the streets or highways within the
corporate limits of the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.65) (Ord. 2859, passed 6-7-1976)
§ 33.136 DISBURSEMENTS.
   Disbursements from the special fund shall be made only upon specific
appropriation by the Council of the city and under order of the Board of Public
Works and Safety of the city for no other purposes than:
   (A)   Payment of the purchase price, rental fees and cost of installation of
the mechanical parking devices;
   (B)   Payment of the cost of maintenance, operation, repair, and all other
incidental costs and expenses in the operation of the mechanical parking
devices, including the cost of clerk and bookkeeping;
   (C)   Payment of the cost of traffic signal devices used in the city and
also repair and maintenance of any of the public streets, including curbs and
sidewalks, and highways where the mechanical parking devices are in use, and
all streets connected therewith in the city;
   (D)   Acquiring by lease or purchase suitable land for off-street parking
facilities; payment of principal and interest on bonds issued to acquire
parking facilities and devices; improvement and maintenance of land for parking
purposes; purchase, installation, and maintenance of mechanical parking devices
on the land; provided the city may either operate or lease the off-street
parking facilities; and
   (E)   Payment of the costs of purchase, maintenance, operation, repair and
all other incidental costs of providing approved school crossing protective
facilities.
(1979 Code, § 33.66) (Ord. 2859, passed 6-7-1976)
COMMUNICATION CENTER FUND
§ 33.155 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   The revenues collected under §
94.086 and all of the revenues remaining in the Fire Alarm Fund shall be placed
in a special fund, known as the Communication Center Fund, and the moneys in
this fund shall be used only for the following purposes: equipment, supplies,
and tools for the maintenance of the integrated city fire alarm system,
including wire, hardware and motor vehicles used in the maintenance of the
system (including repairs thereto), as well as fuel and oil for the vehicles,
and any other equipment, material, and supply costs for which there are funds
available. However, no portion of these funds shall be used for public alarm
boxes, and no portion of these funds shall be used to maintain that part of any
private alarm system more remote from the city system than the owner’s or
occupant’s master box.
(1979 Code, § 33.70) (Ord. 3370, passed 12-9-1981)
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES FUND
§ 33.165 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is established a fund to be known as the Emergency Medical Services
Fund to be used for the provision and maintenance of the necessary equipment,
personnel and facilities for emergency medical services for the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.75) (Ord. 3239, passed 8-25-1980)
Statutory reference:
   Authority to establish, see I.C. 16-31-5
§ 33.166 AUTHORITY.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works and Safety and the Fire Department are
authorized to establish, operate and maintain emergency medical service, to
authorize, franchise or contract for emergency medical services, to establish
appropriate ambulance fees for emergency services provided by the city, and to
take any other actions authorized by I.C. 16-31-5.
   (B)   Any funds so collected by the Board of Public Works and Safety shall
be deposited into the Emergency Medical Services Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.76) (Ord. 3239, passed 8-25-1980)
§ 33.167 APPROPRIATION OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The Council shall appropriate the necessary funds in accordance with
state law from the Emergency Medical Services Fund to defray the expenses of
emergency medical services in the city for each year.
   (B)   Further, the Council is authorized pursuant to I.C. 16-31-5 and I.C.
6-1.1-18.5-1 et seq. and 6-3.5-1-1 et seq. to use tax monies to help defray the
expenses of operating emergency medical services.
(1979 Code, § 33.77) (Ord. 3239, passed 8-25-1980)
PROMOTIONAL FUND
§ 33.185 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   (A)   The “City of Elkhart Promotional Fund” is established.
   (B)   The Council is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the
General Fund or from other funds to pay the expenses incurred in promoting the
betterment of the municipality.
(1979 Code, § 33.80) (Ord. 3389, passed 4-19-1982)
Statutory reference:
   Operation of local government, See I.C. 36-1-3-2
§ 33.186 AUTHORIZED EXPENDITURES.
   Expenditures from the city’s Promotional Fund may include, but are not
necessarily limited to the following:
   (A)   Membership dues in local, regional, state and national associations of
a civic, educational or governmental nature, which have as their purpose the
betterment and improvement of municipal operations;
   (B)   Direct expenses for travel, meals and lodging in conjunction with
municipal business or meetings or organizations to which the municipality
belongs;
   (C)   Expenses incurred in the promotion of economic or industrial
development for the municipality, including meeting room rental, decorations,
meals and travel;
   (D)   Commemorative plaques, certificates or objects such as commemorative
keys; and
   (E)   Other purposes which are deemed by the Mayor to relate directly to
promotion or betterment of the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.81) (Ord. 3389, passed 4-19-1982)
§ 33.187 APPROVAL BY MAYOR PRIOR TO DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.
   (A)   No expenses shall be allowed from the city’s Promotional Fund without
prior authorization and approval of the Mayor.
   (B)   Claims for expenses under this section shall be allowed as prescribed
by §
33.186.
(1979 Code, § 33.82) (Ord. 3389, passed 4-19-1982)
PROBATION USER’S FEE FUND
§ 33.225 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is established a City Court Probation User’s Fee Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.105) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.226 USER’S FEE TO BE COLLECTED FROM DEFENDANTS ON REPORTING PROBATION.
   A user’s fee will be charged and collected from all defendants placed on
reporting probation to the City Court, Probation Department, after December 1,
1985.
(1979 Code, § 33.106) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.227 MAXIMUM RATE OF LEVY.
   The maximum rate of levy under §
33.226 will not exceed:
   (A)   $50 for an initial probation user’s fee; and
   (B)   $10 monthly probation user’s fee for each month, or part thereof, that
the person remains on reporting probation.
(1979 Code, § 33.107) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985; Am. Ord. 4046, passed 1-27-
1992)
§ 33.228 MAXIMUM PAYMENTS FOR PERSONS PLACED ON PROBATION FOR MORE THAN 1
OFFENSE.
   Persons placed on probation for more than 1 offense may not be required to
pay more than:
   (A)   One initial probation user’s fee; and
   (B) One monthly probation user’s fee per month to the Clerk of the Court.
(1979 Code, § 33.108) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.229 FUNDS COLLECTED BY CLERK.
   All moneys for this Fund shall be collected by the City Clerk.
(1979 Code, § 33.109) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.230 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   All moneys collected by the Clerk of the City Court shall be deposited into
the Probation Services Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.110) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.231 USE OF FUNDS.
   The Probation Services Fund shall be used only for probation services. Any
moneys remaining in the fund at the end of the year do not revert to any other
fund, but continue in the Probation Services Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.111) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
§ 33.232 APPROVAL OF STATE BOARD OF TAX COMMISSIONERS.
   This subchapter takes effect upon adoption by the Council and approval by
the Mayor and the State Board of Tax Commissioners, but not before September 1,
1985.
(1979 Code, § 33.112) (Ord. 3642, passed 8-19-1985)
CUMULATIVE SEWER FUND
§ 33.245 NECESSITY OF ESTABLISHING FUND.
   It is declared to be of indispensable public necessity to re-establish
legally a cumulative building and sinking fund, hereinafter referred to as
Cumulative Sewer Fund, to provide funds, to plan, construct, remodel, repair
and extend storm sewers, and for relief sewers and drains in aid of the
sanitary system or storm sewers of the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.120) (Ord. 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.246 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   It is determined to re-establish, provide, and approve a Cumulative Storm
Sewer Fund pursuant to I.C. 36-9-26-1 through 36-9-26-4 and, to provide for the
Cumulative Sewer Fund, Council shall, at the appropriate time, levy a tax at
the rate of $0.20 on each $100 of taxable property in the city.
(1979 Code, § 33.121) (Ord. 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.247 EFFECTIVE DATE OF LEVY.
   The tax shall be first levied in 1988, payable in 1989, and annually
thereafter for a total period of 4 years, including the levy in 1991, payable
in 1992, and expiring thereafter as provided in I.C. 36-9-26-5.
(1979 Code, § 33.122) (Ord. 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.248 PUBLIC HEARING; NOTICE.
   (A)   The Council fixed October 3, 1988, at 7:00 p.m., E.S.T., as the date
and time when the Council in the Council Chambers shall consider and determine
to levy the tax, and the taxpayers of the city then and there had the right to
be heard.
   (B)   The Council does direct the City Clerk, after introduction of this
subchapter and before it is finally enacted, to give notice by publication in
accordance with the provisions of I.C. 5-3-1, as amended, which notice shall
set forth the text of this subchapter, that will include the proposed tax rate,
and the year or years for which it is to be levied, and its purpose.
(1979 Code, § 33.123) (Ord 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.249 APPROVAL OF STATE’S BOARD OF TAX COMMISSIONERS.
   (A)   After the public hearing, and providing this subchapter is duly and
regularly passed, the Council shall submit a copy of this subchapter, duly
certified by the City Clerk, to the state’s Board of Tax Commissioners for its
consideration.
   (B)   This subchapter shall be in full force and effect upon receipt by the
Auditor of Elkhart County, Indiana, of a certification from the state’s Board
of Tax Commissioners approving the tax levy at any amount not to exceed the
levy proposed to be established.
(1979 Code, § 33.124) (Ord. 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.250 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   The taxes, when collected, shall be held in a public depository in a special
fund to be known and designated as Cumulative Sewer Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.125) (Ord. 3644, passed 9-9-1985; Am. Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-
1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-1988)
§ 33.251 FUND USE CONFINED TO CITY LIMITS.
   Funds generated by this levy shall be used only on sewers within the
confines of the city limits.
(1979 Code, § 33.126) (Ord. 3875, passed 8-1-1988; Am. Ord. 3888, passed 10-3-
1988)
ENTERPRISE ZONE ALLOCATION FUND
§ 33.265 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is hereby established the city’s Enterprise Zone Special Zone Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.130) (Ord. 3805, passed 6-1-1987)
§ 33.266 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   Until the end of the enterprise zone phaseout period, the city shall deposit
each year in the Special Zone Fund any amount in the allocation fund derived
from property tax proceeds in excess of those described in I.C. 36-7-14-39(b)
(1) from property located in the enterprise zone that exceeds the amount
sufficient for the purposes specified in I.C. 36-7-14-39 (b)(3) for the year,
all in accordance with the requirements of I.C. 36-7-14-39(g).
(1979 Code, § 33.131) (Ord. 3805, passed 6-1-1987)
§ 33.267 USE OF FUNDS.
   The monies in the Special Zone Fund, based on the recommendations of the
city’s Urban Enterprise Association, shall be used for programs in job
training, job enrichment and basic skill development that are designed to
benefit residents and employers in the enterprise zone or other purposes
specified in I.C. 36-7-14-39(b)(3) as they pertain to that portion of the
allocation area located in the enterprise zone. Those programs shall reserve at
least ½ of their enrollment in any session for residents of the enterprise
zone.
(1979 Code, § 33.132) (Ord. 3805, passed 6-1-1987)

CURB AND GUTTER CONSTRUCTION FUND
§ 33.295 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   (A)   There is established a non-reverting Curb and Gutter Construction Fund
for the sole purpose of installing curbs and gutters in neighborhoods that
predate
Ch. 152 and do not have any curbs and gutters. New subdivisions are not
eligible to use this fund. Areas of the city that have broken or dilapidated
curbs and gutters may utilize this fund for rehabilitation at appropriate unit
charges and only in economic quantities (that is, exceeding 40 lineal feet).
(Ord. 3881, passed 8-16-1988)
   (B)   In recognition of the purpose of this Curb and Gutter Fund to improve
drainage and improve urbanized streetscape standard conformance, planning
cycles for coordination of this effort with storm sewer, catchbasin and inlet
construction and street cross section modification under the Comprehensive
Pavement Rehabilitation Program are hereby established.
(Ord. 4027, passed 5-6-1991)
(1979 Code, § 33.150)
§ 33.296 PETITION REQUIRED.
   (A)   A neighborhood that wishes to have a curb and gutter shall petition
the Board of Public Works and Safety for a curb and gutter. The petition should
include a commitment on the part of the property owners of at least 75% of the
frontage on a block to participate. The participation shall be in proportion to
their property frontage along the block.
   (B)   In a block where a majority of the property owners (i.e. 51%) and at
least 75% of the frontage want curb and gutter, all properties shall be charged
in accordance with §
33.297. If property owners in the minority are unable or unwilling to pay on a
voluntary basis, then the City Attorney shall file a lien for the amount plus
administrative costs against the property.
(1979 Code, § 33.151) (Ord. 3881, passed 8-16-1988; Am. Ord. 4027, passed 5-6-
1991)
§ 33.297 COST OF CONSTRUCTION OR REPLACEMENT.
   Property owners will be charged based on their front footage along the
street where the curb and gutter are to be constructed. In areas where a new
curb and gutter are being installed, this shall be assessed to the property
owner at 75% of the annual street material bid amount as approved by public
bidding by the Board of Public Works. In instances where existing broken or
dilapidated curbing needs to be removed and replaced with a new curb and
gutter, the charge shall be 75% of the annual street materials bid amount as
approved by public bidding by the Board of Public Works. These items will be
added to the annual street materials bid as unit price installed work.
(1979 Code, § 33.152) (Ord. 3881, passed 8-16-1988; Am. Ord. 4027, passed 5-6-
1991)
§ 33.298 METHOD OF PAYMENT; INTEREST RATE.
   (A)   Property owners shall have the option of making a lump sum cash
payment for their share of the curb and gutter construction cost into the Curb
and Gutter Construction Fund or they may enter into an agreement to pay for the
curb and gutter on a time installment plan.
   (B)   The property owner selecting the installment plan must pay 20% of all
fees in advance and then contract to pay for additional principal payments in
the amount of 20% of the construction cost plus interest due on the unpaid
balance. There shall be no penalty for earlier payment. Payment shall be due on
May 2 of years 2 through 5.
   (C)   During December of each calendar year, the Board of Public Works and
Safety shall establish the interest rate for the following year based on the
market rate of borrowing for the city.
   (D)   Application of interest rate. During any calendar year, the interest
rate set by the Board for that year shall apply to all installment contracts
entered into that year by property owners and the city. The initial interest
rate shall continue for the life of each contract initiated in that year.
(1979 Code, § 33.153) (Ord. 3881, passed 8-16-1988)
EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES DISCRETIONARY FUND AND LAW ENFORCEMENT DISCRETIONARY
FUND
§ 33.315 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUNDS.
   There is established the Emergency Medical Services Discretionary Fund and
Law Enforcement Discretionary Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.160) (Ord. 3883, passed 9-12-1988)
§ 33.316 COLLECTION OF FUNDS.
   (A)   A fee of not less than $200, nor more than $1,000, will be charged to
and collected from all defendants:
      (1)   Found to have committed a violation of I.C. 9-30-5, Operating a
Vehicle While Intoxicated, and as subsequently amended from time to time;
      (2)   Who were involved in an accident which resulted in emergency
medical services being provided to any person; and
      (3)   The conviction occurred after the effective date of this
subchapter.
   (B)   All moneys for this fund shall be collected by the City Clerk or the
Clerk of the Court finding the defendant in violation of the above I.C. 9-30-5.
(1979 Code, § 33.161) (Ord. 3883, passed 9-12-1988)
§ 33.317 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   (A)   All moneys collected by the Clerk shall be deposited with the City
Controller who shall:
      (1)   Deposit the greater of 10% or $20 of the emergency medical services
restitution fee to the Law Enforcement Discretionary Fund; and
      (2)   Deposit the remaining balance of the restitution fee to the Fire
Department/Emergency Medical Services Discretionary Fund.
   (B)   All monies deposited into these funds may be spent with or through
appropriation of the Council.
(1979 Code, § 33.162) (Ord. 3883, passed 9-12-1988)
§ 33.318 EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES RESTITUTION FEE.
   (A)   The emergency medical services restitution fee is a charge in addition
to the actual charge to the user of ambulance or emergency medical services.
Payment of the emergency medical services restitution fee does not relieve the
user of the legal obligation to pay the user fee for emergency medical services
nor does it release the defendant from restitution to the victim for actual
expenses incurred by the victim.
   (B)   Payment of the emergency medical services restitution fee may be made
a term of probation and enforced by the court as such. Further, the City
Attorney is empowered to prosecute collection of this fee through civil
litigation or any other means available in addition to enforcement as a term of
probation.
(1979 Code, § 33.163) (Ord. 3883, passed 9-12-1988)
§ 33.319 INABILITY TO PAY.
   In the event the court finds the defendant indigent or unable to pay the
minimum fine hereunder as payment would impose an undue hardship upon the
defendant’s family or dependents, the court has the discretion to impose a
lesser fine or up to 100 hours of community service restitution.
(1979 Code, § 33.164) (Ord. 3883, passed 9-12-1988)
CUMULATIVE FIREFIGHTING BUILDING AND EQUIPMENT AND POLICE RADIO FUND
§ 33.335 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   (A)   There is hereby established the city’s Cumulative Firefighting
Building and Equipment and Police Radio Fund.
   (B)   The city’s Cumulative Firefighting Building and Equipment and Police
Radio Fund is established until such time as the fund is rescinded.
(1979 Code, § 33.170) (Ord. 4318, passed 10-7-1997; Am. Ord. 4975, passed 6-19-
2006 )
§ 33.336 COLLECTION OF FUNDS.
   (A)   An ad valorem property tax levy will be imposed and the revenues from
the levy will be retained in the city’s Cumulative Firefighting Building and
Equipment and Police Radio Fund.
   (B)   The maximum rate of levy under division (A) above will not exceed
$0.033 per $100 assessed valuation for 2006 and thereafter.
(1979 Code, § 33.171) (Ord. 4318, passed 10-7-1997; Am. Ord. 4975, passed 6-19-
2006 )
§ 33.337 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The funds accumulated in the city’s Cumulative Firefighting Building
and Equipment and Police Radio Fund will be used for the following purposes:
      (1)   The purchase, construction, renovation, or addition to buildings,
or the purchase of land, used by the Fire Department;
      (2)   The purchase of firefighting equipment, including making the
required payments under a lease rental with option to purchase agreement made
to acquire such equipment, for the use of the Fire Department;
      (3)   The purchase of police radio equipment; or
      (4)   The purchase, construction, renovation, or addition to a building,
purchase of land, or the purchase of equipment for the use of a provider of
emergency medical services under I.C. 16-31-5 to the city.
   (B)   (1)   Notwithstanding division (A) above, funds accumulated in the
city’s Cumulative Firefighting Building and Equipment and Police Radio Fund may
be spent for purposes other than the purposes stated in division (A) above, if
the purpose is to protect the public health, welfare or safety in an emergency
situation which demands immediate action.
      (2)   Money may be spent under the authority of this division only after
the Mayor issues a declaration that the public health, welfare or safety is in
immediate danger that requires the expenditure of money in the fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.172) (Ord. 4318, passed 10-7-1997; Am. Ord. 4975, passed 6-19-
2006 )

HORIZON FUND
§ 33.375 CREATION OF FUND.
   There is hereby established a fund to be known as the “Horizon Fund” to
receive transfers of funds from the Community Development Block Grant, the
Elkhart Urban Enterprise Association and the Economic Development Income Tax
Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.190) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003)
§ 33.376 PURPOSES OF FUND.
   The funds on deposit in the Horizon Fund shall be used solely to assist
companies interested in purchasing older, obsolete industrial facilities
requiring substantial improvements, by providing a matching grant to cover the
cost to return buildings back to productive use.
(1979 Code, § 33.191) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003)
§ 33.377 LOAN TERMS.
   Twenty percent of the total cost of improvements, up to a maximum of
$200,000 per project may be awarded as a low-interest loan. An applicant shall
be required to submit 2 bids for all construction work, and reimbursement shall
occur after all construction work has been completed and inspected by the city.
Funds will be dispersed in the form of a loan which shall carry a 2.5% interest
rate. The loan shall mature in 5 years and shall have a 20-year amortization.
(1979 Code, § 33.192) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003; Am. Ord. 5179, passed 8-3-
2009)
§ 33.378 APPLICATION AND APPROVAL PROCESS.
   (A)   The Horizon Fund shall be administered by the Elkhart Redevelopment
Commission. Applications shall be submitted to the Department of Planning and
Development for review.
   (B)   Department staff shall review the application for completeness and
prepare a recommendation to the Commission for consideration at a regular Board
meeting.
   (C)   If approved, the company shall sign a forgiveable loan agreement and
submit expenses to the Commission for reimbursement.
(1979 Code, § 33.193) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003)
§ 33.379 NON-REVERTING FUND.
   (A)   Monies deposited in the Horizon Fund shall not revert to other funds
unless the Horizon Fund is terminated by ordinance of the Council.
   (B)   In the event that the Horizon Fund is terminated, any monies in the
Horizon Fund are to be transferred by the City Controller to the General Fund,
unless otherwise directed by the Council.
(1979 Code, § 33.194) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003)
§ 33.380 INITIAL FUNDING.
   The sum of $250,000 is hereby appropriated from the Economic Development
Income Tax Fund and applied to the following account:
 
Other Services and Charges 70-43990-601-03 $250,000
 
(1979 Code, § 33.195) (Ord. 4752, passed 5-23-2003)
RAINY DAY FUND
§ 33.395 CREATION OF FUND.
   There is hereby established a Rainy Day Fund to receive transfers of unused
and unencumbered funds raised by a general or special tax levy on taxable
property of the City of Elkhart whenever the purpose of such tax levy has been
fulfilled and an unused and unencumbered balance remains and to receive
transfers of funds designated for deposit into the Rainy Day Fund from either
the federal or state government.
(1979 Code, § 33.200) (Ord. 4805, passed 3-10-2004)
§ 33.396 PURPOSES OF FUND.
   The funds on deposit in the Rainy Day Fund may be used solely for the
operation of the city and its various departments, if the city is without
sufficient levies or funds to pay such costs, including, but not limited to
salaries and wages, costs of services, supplies, equipment, capital
improvements, repairs and similar expenditures.
(1979 Code, § 33.201) (Ord. 4805, passed 3-10-2004)
§ 33.397 TRANSFERS TO FUND.
   On or before December 31 of each year, the City Controller shall transfer
the unused and unencumbered funds remaining from the general or special tax
levy to the Rainy Day Fund plus 25% of each year’s ambulance fees fund. In any
fiscal year, such transfer may not exceed 10% of the city’s total budget for
that fiscal year.
(1979 Code, § 33.202) (Ord. 4805, passed 3-10-2004)
§ 33.398 APPROPRIATIONS FROM FUND.
   The Council shall authorize the expenditure of funds from the Rainy Day Fund
by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds that receive tax
monies upon making a finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent
with the intent of the fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.203) (Ord. 4805, passed 3-10-2004)
§ 33.399 NON-REVERTING FUND.
   Monies deposited in the Rainy Day Fund shall not revert to other funds
unless the Rainy Day Fund is terminated by ordinance of the Council. In the
event that the Rainy Day Fund is terminated, any monies in the Rainy Day Fund
are to be transferred by the City Controller to the General Fund.
(1979 Code, § 33.204) (Ord. 4805, passed 3-10-2004)
PAYMENT FOR CLAIMS
§ 33.415 CLAIMS SUBMITTED PRIOR TO BOARD ALLOWANCE.
   Pursuant to I.C. 36-4-8-14, the City Controller is hereby authorized to make
advance payment for claims submitted prior to board allowance for the following
kinds of expenses:
   (A)   Property or services purchased or leased from the United States
government, its agencies or its political subdivisions;
   (B)   License or permit fees;
   (C)   Insurance premiums;
   (D)   Utility payments or utility connection charges;
   (E)   General grant programs where advance funding is not prohibited and the
contracting party posts sufficient security to cover the amount advanced;
   (F)   Grants of state funds authorized by statute;
   (G)   Maintenance or service agreements;
   (H)   Leases or rental agreements;
   (I)   Bond or coupon payments;
   (J)   Payroll;
   (K)   State, federal or county taxes;
   (L)   Expenses that must be paid because of emergency circumstances; and
   (M)   Expenses described in an ordinance.
(1979 Code, § 33.210) (Ord. 4813, passed 3-18-2004)
§ 33.416 ADDITIONAL CLAIMS.
   In addition to the payment of expenses enumerated in §
33.415, as authorized by I.C. 36-4-8-14(b)(13), advance payment of claims for
the following kinds of expenses is hereby authorized:
   (A)   Fees charged by the County Recorder and County Auditor for recording
of documents;
   (B)   Registration fees for seminars and travel expenses.
(1979 Code, § 33.211) (Ord. 4813, passed 3-18-2004)
§ 33.417 SUPPORT FOR PAYMENTS.
   Each payment of expenses under this subchapter must be supported by a fully
itemized invoice or bill and certification by the City Controller. The Board of
Public Works shall review and allow the claim at its next regular or special
meeting following the pre- approved payment of the expense.
(1979 Code, § 33.212) (Ord. 4813, passed 3-18-2004)

ELECTRONIC FUND TRANSACTIONS
§ 33.475 CITY CONTROLLER TO MAKE TRANSACTIONS.
   (A)   Pursuant to I.C. 5-13-5-5, the City Controller is hereby authorized to
transact the city's business with a financial institution or a retirement fund
administered by the Public Employees' Retirement Fund through the use of
electronic fund transfers; and to further invest in certificates of deposit of
depositories which have been designated by the State Board of Finance as a
depository for state deposits under I.C. 5-13-9.5 et seq., as well as invest in
securities backed by the full faith and credit of the United States Treasury or
fully guaranteed by the United States according to I.C. 5-13-9 et seq.
   (B)   The following transactions may be conducted by electronic fund
transfers: all transactions related to payroll; police and fire pension;
federal, state and county funding deposits; as well as infrequent and/or other
transactions required by law or a third party.
   (C)   The funds shall be deposited in a financial institution, as that term
is defined by I.C. 5-13-6-1.
   (D)   The funds may be deposited in a financial institution, as that term is
defined by I.C. 5-13-5-1, that has an office in the city.
   (E)   The City Controller shall deposit all funds not later than the next
business day following the receipt of funds in depositories that are approved
for state funds.
   (F)   The City Controller shall maintain records and documentation as are
adequate of the transaction conducted so that they may be audited as provided
by law.
(Ord. 4855, passed 10-7-2004)
OFF-STREET PARKING  ENFORCEMENT FUND
§ 33.485 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a special non-reverting fund, which shall be
known as the Off-Street Parking Enforcement Fund into which shall be deposited
all fines collected by the City Court for violations of the off-street parking
regulations contained in the Zoning Ordinance (Ord. 4370 as amended). All
monies remaining in the Fund at the end of each year shall remain in the Fund
and shall not revert to the General Fund.
(Ord. 5005, passed 12-18-2006)
§ 33.486 DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.
   All fines collected for violations of the parking regulations contained in
the Zoning Ordinance shall be deposited into the Off-Street Parking Enforcement
Fund and in no other place. The Common Council may transfer monies into the
Fund when necessary to advance a public purpose.
(Ord. 5005, passed 12-18-2006)
§ 33.487 USE OF FUNDS.
   Appropriations from the Fund shall be used to fund zoning enforcement
activities in areas within the city designated as "focus areas" by the Director
of the Office of Planning and Development. Such zoning enforcement activities
shall include, but not be limited to: signs, literature and advertising or
promotional materials, designed to inform the public about the city's off-
street parking regulations and their applications; the purchase of cameras for
documenting zoning violations; the printing of ticket forms; the labor cost and
other costs associated with increased enforcement activities or other
activities related to combating illegal off-street parking; and other similar
measures designed to reduce zoning violations within the city.
(Ord. 5005, passed 12-18-2006)

§ 33.497 CUSTODIAN OF PETTY CASH FUNDS.
   (A)   The City Controller is authorized to issue the warrants necessary in
the appropriate fund in favor of the individuals occupying the designated
positions above in order to maintain the funds established by this subchapter
upon a claim for same approved by the appropriate governing board.
   (B)   The custodians shall each use his or her petty cash fund to pay small
or emergency items of operating expenses. A proper expenditure from the petty
cash fund cannot be made without a receipt having been obtained for said
expenditure.
   (C)   Each custodian shall file, at least quarterly, a claim with the
appropriate governing board attaching with it all original receipts totaling
the cash claimed to be expended so that the petty cash fund may be reimbursed
for these expenditures, and the claim for reimbursement of the petty cash fund
shall be approved and made in the same manner as is required for other
expenditures of the city.
(Ord. 4964, passed 4-17-2006; Am. Ord. 5225, passed 9-13-2010; Am. Ord. 5342,
passed 6-3- 2013)
LOCAL MAJOR MOVES CONSTRUCTION FUND
§ 33.500 ESTABLISHMENT OF FUND.
   There is hereby established the Elkhart City Major Moves Construction Fund,
as contemplated by the House Enrolled Act No. 1008 and I.C. 8-14-16-4(a)
forming a part thereof (hereinafter the "Fund").
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.501 EXPENDITURES FROM THE FUND.
   (A)   Monies in the Fund may be expended only:
      (1)   For the purposes set forth in I.C. 8-14-16-5, as such was
incorporated in House Enrolled Act No. 1008, and as such shall from time to
time hereinafter be amended or expanded; and
      (2)   In a fashion consistent with the provisions of this subchapter.
   (B)   Monies in the Fund shall consist of:
      (1)   The original allocation to city government from the State of
Indiana Major Moves Construction Fund;
      (2)   Monies received hereafter from other state, federal, or local
sources; and
      (3)   Monies repaid to the Fund from advancements made from the Fund and
from interest earnings on advancements, or other investment earnings in the
Fund.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.502 REGULATION ON USE AND INVESTMENT OF MONIES IN THE FUND.
   Subject to §§
33.504 and
33.506, the following are goals, standards, and procedures herewith adopted by
the Common Council to be followed relative to the investment of monies in the
Fund, the appropriation of monies from the Fund for projects or undertakings
permitted by law, the repayment of monies advanced from the Fund, the earning
of interest or other returns on monies within the Fund or advanced from the
Fund, and the processing of proposals for consideration by the Mayor and the
Common Council to be paid for by monies appropriated by the Fund.
   (A)   Monies in the Fund are to grow, over time, through interest earnings
and other returns on investments, to serve as a perpetual resource for projects
or other undertakings permitted by law using monies within the Fund.
   (B)   Except in the case of approved road maintenance programs, as set forth
in §
33.504, appropriations from the Fund shall be repaid to the Fund, with
interest; when interest is applicable, the interest rate to be attached to any
appropriation of monies, which interest is to thus be repaid to the Fund in
addition to return of the amounts so appropriated, shall be established as part
of the documentation contemplated by §
33.506, with such interest rate to generally approximate the floating average
interest rate received by the City Controller on generally pooled investment
funds of the city consistent with I.C. 5-13-9.
   (C)   All requests for the appropriation of monies from the Fund for legally
permitted projects and undertakings shall first be submitted to, and reviewed
by, the Expenditure Review Committee as defined in §
33.503. No request for monies from the Fund shall be approved by the Mayor and
submitted to the Common Council for formal appropriation, unless and until the
Expenditure Review Committee has reviewed the request, and submitted to the
Mayor and Common Council jointly a report, which report shall address and/or
consider:
      (1)   The merits of the project and undertaking for which the request has
been submitted;
      (2)   The ability of city government, directly or indirectly, through
available funding sources, to repay any appropriation, with requisite interest,
where required;
      (3)   The appropriate interest rate to be imposed upon the appropriation
of such monies, and to be made a part of the repayment program for such, where
applicable;
      (4)   The propriety and importance of such request and the proposed
appropriation from the Fund relative to other projects and undertakings for
city government generally which may be supported by appropriations from the
Fund; and
      (5)   Whether the request for appropriation can be directly funded from
other available sources in a practical or efficient matter.
   (D)   In addition to the goals, standards and procedures set forth herein,
appropriations of monies from the Fund shall be in compliance with House
Enrolled Act No. 1008, and in particular I.C. 8-14-16-4(d).
   (E)   Consistent with I.C. 8-14-16(4)(c), and I.C. 5-13-9, the City
Controller shall administer the monies in the Fund, and shall be authorized to
pool such monies, subject to specific and separate accounting and recordkeeping
procedures, with other city investment funds.
   (F)   As part of the annual budgetary process for city government, the
Expenditure Review Committee shall establish the actual or projected fund
balance as of each applicable January 1, commencing with January 1, 2009. The
fund balance shall consist of all monies attributable to or related to the
Local Major Moves Construction Fund, to include monies as yet unused and
unappropriated, all appropriated amounts within the Fund, but not yet withdrawn
from such, all monies loaned or advanced from the Fund, subject to
documentation and repayment programs as set forth in §
33.506, all earned and accrued interest due on repayment programs, but not yet
paid into the Fund, all accrued interest forming a part of the monies within
the Fund, and all interest contemplated to be accrued on monies within the Fund
and/or contemplated to be accrued on repayment programs to and including the
applicable January 1 date. Excluded from the fund balance, for purposes of such
definition and determination, shall be appropriated but not yet advanced monies
contemplated for road maintenance programs, which appropriations shall take
place prior to the applicable January 1.
   (G)   The principal amount of monies advanced under repayment programs shall
not, at any time, exceed 50% of the then current fund balance as computed per
division (F) above.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.503 EXPENDITURE REVIEW COMMITTEE.
   There is herewith established the Expenditure Review Committee relative to
the Fund. The Expenditure Review Committee shall consist of the City
Controller, the City Street Commissioner and the City Economic Development
Manager. Any request for appropriations from the Fund shall be submitted to and
reviewed by the Expenditure Review Committee, consistent with provisions of §§
33.502 and
33.504. Chairperson of the Expenditure Review Committee shall be the City
Controller. The Expenditure Review Committee shall meet periodically as
determined by the Chairperson or by majority vote of the members of the
Expenditure Review Committee. The Expenditure Review Committee shall
specifically meet prior to the submission by the Mayor of the proposed budget
and capital expenditures programs for each annual budget of city government, so
that requests for appropriations from the Fund may be properly reviewed, and
the required report relative to any requests submitted to the Mayor and the
Common Council, as part of the annual budgetary process for the city
government.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.504 ROAD MAINTENANCE PROGRAMS.
   It is recognized by the Common Council that there is a perpetual and growing
need for the maintenance, repair, paving, preservation, and upgrading of the
roads and streets under the jurisdiction of city government, and that the
Street Department and Department of Public Works, develop plans, projects, and
programs for such, and seek appropriations and allocations of monies by the
Common Council therefore, as part of the annual budgetary process, and
otherwise. Such undertakings are herewith referred to as road maintenance
programs. Requests for use of monies from the Fund for road maintenance
programs shall be submitted annually to the Expenditure Review Committee, as
part of the regular budgetary process. The following additional or altered
goals, standards, and procedures shall apply relative to such road maintenance
programs:
   (A)   A portion of the accumulated earnings from the Fund shall be
appropriated annually by the Common Council for road maintenance programs.
   (B)   The amount of such annual appropriation for road maintenance programs
shall be determined by the Common Council, after the Expenditure Review
Committee has submitted its report to the Mayor and the Common Council, and the
Mayor has submitted to the Common Council the desired appropriation amount from
the Fund for road maintenance programs.
   (C)   Monies appropriated for road maintenance programs shall not be subject
to the otherwise existing repayment standard or the otherwise existing payment
of interest on appropriated monies from the Fund, it being established that
expenditures from the Fund for road maintenance programs shall be exempt from
such repayment and interest payment standards.
   (D)   No appropriation of monies from the Fund for road maintenance programs
shall cause the targeted growth rate for the Fund, set forth in §
33.505, to go unattained, on a regular and ongoing basis, though due to
fluctuations in interest rates, during the course of any 12-month cycle,
interest earnings on monies in the Fund may be adversely affected, which
adverse impact, if any, shall be considered relative to future appropriations
for road maintenance programs from the Fund by the Mayor, Common Council, and
Expenditure Review Committee, so as to stabilize and restore the desired target
growth rate(s).
   (E)   Appropriations from the Fund for road maintenance programs shall not
require the documentation contemplated by §
33.506.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.505 TARGET GROWTH RATES.
   (A)   Monies in the Fund shall grow, on an annualized basis, so that the
interest earned by monies in the Fund, and interest paid back on appropriations
from the Fund subject to repayment programs, collectively exceed appropriations
for road maintenance programs. Annually, and as part of the budgetary process
for city government generally, the Expenditure Review Committee, using the best
economic records and information available, shall recommend to the Mayor and
the Common Council a target growth rate for the succeeding calendar year,
commencing with the calendar year 2009; the target growth rate for the calendar
year 2008 is stipulated by the Common Council to be 1.9%. The target growth
rate to be recommended by the Expenditure Review Committee, subject to actual
approval by the Mayor and the Common Council, shall not be less than 30% nor
more than 50% of the projected interest earnings by the Fund for the succeeding
calendar year. The approval of the target growth rate by the Mayor and the
Common Council shall take place as part of the annual budgetary process for
city government; should the Mayor and Common Council be unable to agree upon
the target growth rate, the target growth rate recommended by the Expenditure
Review Committee shall control for the succeeding calendar year.
   (B)   An example of establishing the target growth rate (for illustrative
purposes only) is as follows:
      (1)   Assume the Fund balance as projected by the Expenditure Review
Committee as of January 1, 2008 to be $26,500,000.
      (2)   Assume that earnings on loaned and advanced monies, as well as
earnings on monies retained within the Fund, shall average 5% per annum for the
calendar year 2008, giving rise to projected interest earnings of $1,325,000.
      (3)   Assume that the Expenditure Review Committee recommends that 80% of
such interest earnings shall be appropriated for road maintenance programs per
annum, which recommendation shall be accepted by the Mayor and Common Council.
If 80% of the interest earnings are targeted for road maintenance programs, the
balance of the interest earnings, to-wit: 20%, shall be added to and become a
part of the Fund and ultimately the Fund balance; 20% of the 5% interest
earnings represents a 1% target growth rate; 20% of the projected interest
earnings would be $265,000 to be added to the Fund balance. The appropriation
for road maintenance programs, out of such interest earnings, would be in the
amount of $1,060,000 under the example herein set forth.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
§ 33.506 DOCUMENTATION.
   With the exception of appropriations for road maintenance programs, no
appropriation of monies from the Fund shall be made without documentation that
requires repayment of the monies appropriated and states the interest rate, and
method of payment of accruing interest, applicable to the monies so
appropriated. Such documentation shall define the contemplated sources of
revenue for the repayment of the monies advanced and the interest accruing, and
shall be in such form, and contain such standards, pledges, and remedies as the
Expenditure Review Committee shall require.
(Ord. 5086, passed 12-17-2007)
ELKHART CAPITAL OUTLAY FUND
§ 33.510 ESTABLISHMENT.
   (A)   Creation of Fund. There is hereby established an "Elkhart Capital
Outlay Fund" to receive transfers of unused and unencumbered funds raised by a
general or special tax levy on taxable property of the city.
   (B)   Purposes of Fund. The funds on deposit in the Elkhart Capital Outlay
Fund may be used solely for any expenses related to projects or equipment
estimated by the City Controller to have a total cost in excess of $ 100,000.
   (C)   Transfers to Fund. On or before March 1 of each year, the City
Controller may transfer an amount not to exceed $500,000 of the unused and
unencumbered funds remaining from the general or special tax levy from the
previous calendar year to the Elkhart Capital Outlay Fund.
   (D)   Appropriations from the Fund. The Common Council shall authorize the
expenditure of funds from the Elkhart Capital Outlay Fund by appropriations
made in the same manner as other funds that receive tax monies upon making a
finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent with the intent of the
Fund.
   (E)   Non-reverting Fund. Monies deposited in the Elkhart Capital Outlay
Fund shall not revert to other funds unless the Elkhart Capital Outlay Fund is
terminated by ordinance of the Common Council. In the event that the Elkhart
Capital Outlay Fund is terminated, any monies in the Elkhart Capital Outlay
Fund are to be transferred by the City Controller to the General Fund.
(Ord. 5640, passed 1-8-2018)
