BICYCLES; SKATEBOARDS
§ 73.01 OPERATORS TO CONFORM TO MOTOR VEHICLE RULES.
   (A)   For purposes of this chapter, BICYCLE shall mean any foot-propelled
vehicle, irrespective of the number of wheels in contact with the ground.
   (B)   Operators of bicycles, when on a public highway or street, shall
conform to the rules established for the operation of motor vehicles, including
the directions and the instructions of official traffic-control signals and
devices applicable to vehicles, unless otherwise directed by a police officer.
(1979 Code, § 73.01) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961; Am. Ord. 5278, passed 10-17-
2011 )
Penalty, see § 73.99
Statutory reference:
   Local regulation of operation of bicycles, see I.C. 9-21-1-3
§ 73.02 NUMBER OF RIDERS; INVERTING FRAME OR SPROCKET.
   (A)   Not more than 1 person shall ride upon a bicycle unless the bicycle is
designed, manufactured and equipped with 2 or more separated sprockets, handle
bars and seats.
   (B)   No person shall ride or operate any bicycle on any public highway,
street, sidewalk, alley or upon any public path set aside for the use of
bicycles, which shall be built, constructed or manufactured by inverting the
frame and sprocket in such a manner that the operator is unable to balance the
bicycle with 1 foot on the ground while seated in a normal riding position on
the bicycle.
(1979 Code, § 73.02) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961; Am. Ord. 2060, passed 12-21-
1964)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.03 OPERATION OF BICYCLES.
   Bicycles shall be operated as close to the right- hand edge of the highway
or street as is possible, and in single file when passing other vehicles,
parked or moving, or any other considerable object in the highway. Bicycles
shall not be ridden more than 2 abreast at any time.
(1979 Code, § 73.03) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-61)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.04 RECKLESS OPERATION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall operate a bicycle in a reckless manner.
(1979 Code, § 73.04) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.05 RIDING OF BICYCLES AND SKATEBOARDS PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS;
RIGHT-OF-WAY YIELDED TO PEDESTRIAN.
   No person shall ride a bicycle or skateboard upon any sidewalk within the
city in the area bounded by and including the west sidewalk of Second Street,
the east sidewalk of Main Street, the south sidewalk of Jackson Blvd., and the
south sidewalk of Tyler Street, nor upon any public parking lot in the
designated area. Otherwise, when any person is riding a bicycle or skateboard
upon a sidewalk, such person shall yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian and
shall give an audible signal a reasonable time before overtaking or passing
such pedestrian.
(1979 Code, § 73.05) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961; Am. Ord. 3920, passed 6-6-
1989; Am. Ord. 5278, passed 10-17-2011 )
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.06 REQUIRED PASSING DISTANCE.
   (A)   An operator of a motor vehicle driving on any public road must provide
a minimum distance of 3 feet between the motor vehicle and a bicyclist when
passing the bicyclist. If the motor vehicle operator cannot safely provide 3
feet of distance, then the motor vehicle operator must wait to pass the
bicyclist until it is possible to do so while providing the required passing
distance. The driver shall not return to the original lane until the vehicle
has passed and is safely clear of the bicyclist.
   (B)   The Police Department shall enforce the terms of this section and
issue citations for violations of this section.
(Ord. 5397, passed 8-4-2014) Penalty, see §
73.99
§ 73.07 LIGHTS AND REFLECTOR.
   Bicycles while being operated during the period of darkness shall display a
white light on the front thereof, the lamp to be securely fastened to the
bicycle, and plainly visible from a distance of 300 feet ahead under normal
atmospheric conditions. They shall also display a red reflector on the rear
thereof, which shall be plainly visible at night in the lawful lights of motor
vehicles for a distance of 200 feet to the rear under similar conditions.
(1979 Code, § 73.07) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.08 BELL OR WARNING DEVICE.
   No person shall ride a bicycle unless it is equipped with a suitable bell or
other warning device audible for a distance of 100 feet or more. However, the
warning device must not be a whistle or siren.
(1979 Code, § 73.08) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.09 SPEED.
   No person shall operate his or her bicycle at a speed greater than will
permit him to bring his or her vehicle to a stop within the assured clear
distance ahead.
(1979 Code, § 73.09) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.10 PARKING.
   No person shall park a bicycle upon a street except against the curb or upon
a sidewalk in a rack to support the bicycle or against a building, or at the
curb in such manner as to afford the least obstruction to vehicular or
pedestrian traffic.
(1979 Code, § 73.10) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.11 BRAKES.
   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator
to make the braked wheel skid on a dry, level and clean pavement.
(1979 Code, § 73.11) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.12 APPLICATION OF BICYCLE AND SKATEBOARD REGULATIONS.
   (A)   The provisions of §§
73.01 through
73.14 shall apply whenever a bicycle or skateboard is operated upon any street,
sidewalk or alley or upon any public path set aside for the exclusive use of
bicycles or skateboards subject to those exception stated herein.
   (B)   No parent or guardian shall authorize or knowingly permit his or her
child or ward to violate any of the provisions of §§
73.01 through
73.14.
(1979 Code, § 73.12) (Ord. 1894, passed 4-19-1961; Am. Ord. 3920, passed 6-6-
1989)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.13 LICENSING REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS; LICENSING RULES.
   (A)   Ninety days after the passage, approval and publication of §§
73.01 through
73.14, no person shall ride or propel a bicycle upon any street, sidewalk,
alley or any public path set aside for the exclusive use of bicycles, unless
the bicycle has been licensed and a license plate is attached as provided
herein. However, a license shall not be required, but may be purchased, for a
bicycle the wheels of which are less than 20 inches in diameter. The provisions
of this section shall not apply to any bicycle owner or rider from another city
or community who is therein licensed in accordance with provisions
substantially like those set forth in this section. A rider from without the
city limits who is not licensed and is operating his or her bicycle within the
city limits may then register his or her bicycle and purchase a license for his
or her protection.
   (B)   Registration of permanent bicycle titles and licenses shall be made at
the place or places designated as licensing agencies from time to time by the
Controller of the city, on forms provided by the Police Department. Each
bicycle shall be presented at such place or places in order to receive a
permanent registration number. A license fee of $0.50 shall be paid by the
owner to the Controller and the Controller’s receipt shall be exhibited by the
owner to the licensing agent when the owner applies for registration. The
registration is to be issued in triplicate form. The original shall be filed in
the Elkhart Police Department, 1 copy shall be delivered to the bicycle owner
and 1 copy shall be filed in the Controller’s office.
   (C)   A license shall not be issued for any bicycle if the licensing agent
has reasonable grounds to believe that the applicant is not the owner or
entitled to the possession of the bicycle.
   (D)   The Police Department shall keep a permanent record of the number of
each bicycle license, the date it is issued, the name of the person to whom it
is issued and the number on the frame of the bicycle for which it is issued.
The Controller shall have the responsibility of ordering and maintaining all
supplies, which shall be paid for out of these license fees.
   (E)   The license plates shall be firmly attached to the steering post of
the bicycle by the licensing agent, and will bear the number stamped by the
licensing agent in a designated spot on the crank housing of the bicycle.
   (F)   No person shall remove a license plate from a bicycle except when the
bicycle is dismantled or when it is no longer operated in the city. Upon
transfer of ownership, the transfer shall be made on the title showing the date
of transfer and the signature of the owner and parent or guardian.
   (G)   The licensing agent shall inspect each bicycle before licensing it and
shall not license any bicycle which is determined to be in an unsafe mechanical
condition.
   (H)   In the event a license plate is lost or stolen, upon application to
the Police Department, and the payment of a $0.25 fee, a duplicate registration
plate shall be issued.
   (I)   Every person engaged in the business of buying or selling new or
second-hand bicycles shall, within seven days after each purchase or sale, make
a report to the Police Department of each used bicycle purchased and of each
bicycle sold by the dealer, giving the name and address of the person from whom
purchased or to whom sold, a description of the bicycle by name or make, the
frame number and the number of the license plate, if any.
(1979 Code, § 73.13) (Ord. 1894, passed 7-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.14 APPEARANCE BEFORE JUVENILE DIVISION OF POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   Upon the violation of any of the provisions of §§
73.01 through
73.14 by any person, the person may be served with a citation to appear before
the Chief Officer of the Juvenile Division of the Police Department, and the
owner, if a minor, must be accompanied by 1 or more of his or her parents or
guardians in answering the citation, or the owner may be prosecuted as provided
by state law in the case of ordinance violations.
(1979 Code, § 73.14) (Ord. 1894, passed 7-19-1961)
Penalty, see § 73.99
ANIMALS AND HORSE-DRAWN VEHICLES
§ 73.25 RIDING OR DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS OR FOOTPATHS.
   No person shall ride or drive a horse, or other animal or any vehicle upon
any sidewalk or footpath along any of the streets of the city, unless necessary
to cross the sidewalk or footpath.
(1979 Code, § 73.20) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.26 RIDING OR DRIVING ON LAWNS OR PARKWAYS.
   No person shall ride any horse or other animal, or drive any vehicle over
any parkway or lawn along the streets of the city. Nor shall any person ride a
horse or other animal so as to enter or encroach upon lawns or parkways of the
streets, or to damage the lawns or parkways and the plants, shrubs and trees
thereon.
(1979 Code, § 73.21) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.27 RIDING OR DRIVING FASTER THAN A TROT.
   No person shall ride or drive any horse or any other animal over any street
or alley of the city faster than an ordinary trot.
(1979 Code, § 73.22) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.28 STOPPING ON SIDEWALKS, FOOTPATHS OR CROSSWALKS.
   No person shall stop any horse, animal or vehicle on or over any sidewalk,
footpath or crosswalk.
(1979 Code, § 73.23) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.29 RIDING OR DRIVING IN RECKLESS MANNER.
   No person shall ride or drive any horse or pony upon any of the streets of
the city in a reckless manner, or in a manner which endangers the property or
the life and limb of any person.
(1979 Code, § 73.24) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.30 RIDING MORE THAN 2 ABREAST.
   Persons riding horses upon roadways of any street in the city shall not ride
more than 2 abreast.
(1979 Code, § 73.25) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.31 CONDUCT.
   No person riding any horse, or persons riding horses, or riding in a horse-
drawn vehicle, upon any of the streets of the city shall yell, make undue noise
or conduct himself or herself in a hilarious manner.
(1979 Code, § 73.26) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.32 ANNOYANCES AND NUISANCES.
   (A)   No person shall ride a horse or any other animal, or drive any horse-
drawn vehicle along the roadway of any street or alley in the city in such a
manner as to be an annoyance or a nuisance to the residents of the street or
neighborhood.
   (B)   The riding of a horse or any other animal continuously and repeatedly
upon any street, riding in groups of more than 4, riding faster than an
ordinary trot, or raising clouds of dust shall be an annoyance prohibited in
division (A) above.
(1979 Code, § 73.27) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.33 LIMITATIONS ON APPLICABILITY.
   Sections
73.25 and through
73.35 shall not apply to dogs, bicycles, tricycles, small wagons, pushcarts,
baby carriages or other vehicles commonly used by children in play.
(1979 Code, § 73.28) (Ord. 1346, passed 9-12-1942)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.34 LEAVING ANIMALS UNATTENDED OR UNFASTENED.
   No person shall leave any draft horses or animal in any street, alley or
public place of the city unless some person able to control it shall remain
with it or in the near vicinity thereof, or unless the animal shall be securely
fastened to a hitching post or rack.
(1979 Code, § 73.29) (Ord. 546, passed 4-5-1911)
Penalty, see § 73.99
§ 73.35 HITCHING ANIMALS TO SHADE OR ORNAMENTAL TREES.
   It shall be unlawful to hitch any horse, mule or team to any shade or
ornamental trees or boxing around the trees belonging to any person or to the
city.
(1979 Code, § 73.35) (Ord. 553, passed 5-20-1911)
Penalty, see § 70.999
§ 73.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   (1)   Any person who violates any provision of §§
73.01 through
73.05 and
73.07 through
73.14 shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than $1, nor more than $100.
      (2)   Any person found to be in violation of §
73.06 shall be fined in the amount of $25. Each occurrence that is in violation
of §
73.06 shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1894, passed 7-19-1961; Am. Ord. 3920, passed 6-6-1989; Am. Ord. 5397,
passed 8-4-2014)
   (B) Any person who violates §
73.34 shall, upon conviction, be fined in any sum not exceeding $25.
(Ord. 546, passed 4-5-1911)
   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation who violates any provision of this
chapter for which another penalty is not specifically provided shall, upon
conviction, be subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed upon each day during which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 74: TRUCKS
Section
   
74.01   Truck defined
   
74.02   Trucks not to pass other trucks; exception
   
74.03   Trucks to remain prescribed distance apart
   
74.04   Preferential and nondesignated streets
 
   
74.99   Penalty
§ 74.01 TRUCK DEFINED.
   For the purposes of this chapter, a TRUCK is any vehicle designed or
operated for the transportation of property of any kind and whose body weight
or combined body and load weight exceeds 10,000 pounds.
(1979 Code, § 74.01) (Ord. 1668, passed 7-16-1957)
§ 74.02 TRUCKS NOT TO PASS OTHER TRUCKS; EXCEPTION.
   No truck while being operated within the city limits shall pass another
truck traveling in the same direction, except when necessary to comply with any
law then in full force and effect.
(1979 Code, § 74.02) (Ord. 1668, passed 7-16-1957)
§ 74.03 TRUCKS TO REMAIN PRESCRIBED DISTANCE APART.
   No truck shall approach another truck upon any street or alley within the
city limits, which is traveling in the same direction, nearer than 100 feet
except when necessary to comply with any law which is then in full force and
effect or at traffic lights.
(1979 Code, § 74.03) (Ord. 1668, passed 7-16-1957)
§ 74.04 PREFERENTIAL AND NONDESIGNATED STREETS.
   (A)   Streets or portions of streets not designated in
Ch. 78, Schedule II(A) as truck routes, and streets or portions of streets not
designated in
Ch. 78 Schedule II(B) as restrictive streets are hereby defined as
nondesignated streets.
   (B)   A person, firm or corporation shall not operate or cause to be
operated any truck or freight- carrying vehicle with a gross weight in excess
of ten tons on any street or highway under the jurisdiction of the city except
on a truck route; as provided in divisions (C) and (D) below; or when providing
local services within the city including, but not limited to pickup and
delivery, emergency, maintenance, utility and protective services, between 5:00
a.m. and 7:00 p.m. local time.
   (C)   Any such vehicle having an origin, destination or a series of 2 or
more destinations on a truck route, restrictive street or on nondesignated
street or streets may use nondesignated streets to the extent reasonably
necessary to minimize total distance traveled, provided the route traveled
between the points is reasonably direct.
   (D)   Any vehicle having an origin or a destination on a restrictive street
shall enter and leave the street at the closest intersection to the
destination, and shall traverse the restrictive street the shortest possible
distance.
   (E)   The Traffic Engineer of the city is empowered to post restrictive
streets and truck routes by appropriate signs.
   (F)   The Police Department of the city is authorized and directed to
enforce the provisions of this section.
(1979 Code, § 74.04) (Ord. 3227, passed 7-21-1980; Am. Ord. 4648, passed 1-14-
2002) Penalty, see
§ 74.99
§ 74.99 PENALTY.
   The penalty for operating or causing to be operated any vehicle in violation
of this chapter shall be a fine not to exceed $1,000. Each violation shall
constitute a separate offense.
(1979 Code, § 74.99) (Ord. 3227, passed 7-21-1980; Am. Ord. 4648, passed 1-14-
2002)
CHAPTER 75: SNOW ROUTES
Section
   
75.01   Definitions
   
75.02   General provisions
   
75.03   Offenses
   
75.04   Emergency snow removal on residential streets
 
   
75.99   Penalty
§ 75.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   SNOW. Any precipitation depositing any accumulation on the streets,
including snow, sleet, hail, ice and freezing rain.
   SNOW REMOVAL COORDINATOR. The Mayor of the city or the person or agents of
the person designated by the Mayor.
   SNOW REMOVAL CONDITIONS. A state of street conditions that are hazardous and
dangerous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic due to severe winter conditions
when and so declared by the Snow Removal Coordinator.
   SNOW ROUTES. All streets in the city so designated by the Council and marked
by appropriate signs.
   VEHICLES. All self-propelled motorized vehicles.
(1979 Code, § 75.01) (Ord. 2694, passed 11-19-1973; Am. Ord. 3396, passed 5-24-
1982)
§ 75.02 GENERAL PROVISIONS.
   (A)   The Council shall, by regulation, designate streets which are heavily
traveled and are necessary thoroughfares throughout the city as “snow routes.”
   (B)   The Council may amend, modify or add to the list of snow routes, as
set forth in Chapter 78, Schedule VI.
   (C)   All streets designated in Chapter 78, Schedule VI as “snow routes”
shall be posted with suitable signs or markers.
   (D)   When, in the opinion of the Snow Removal Coordinator, the actual or
expected precipitation of snow will create hazardous or dangerous highway
conditions for vehicular or pedestrian traffic, he or she shall have authority
to declare a “snow removal condition”:
      (1)   When a snow emergency condition has been declared, the Coordinator
immediately shall inform the public by issuing a statement to the news media,
including radio, television and newspapers.
      (2)   The snow emergency condition, once declared, shall continue in
force and effect until the Coordinator declares it to be terminated. The
termination shall be communicated to the citizens of the city in the same
manner as notice of the condition was given.
(1979 Code, § 75.02) (Ord. 2694, passed 11-19-1973; Am. Ord. 3396, passed 5-24-
1982) Penalty, see
§ 75.99
§ 75.03 OFFENSES.
   From and after the time when a snow emergency condition has been declared as
set forth in §
75.02(D) and until it has been terminated:
   (A)   No vehicle shall be parked on any snow route, as set forth in Chapter
78, Schedule VI, unless permission for parking is expressly granted by the Snow
Removal Coordinator in his or her notice of the existence of a snow emergency
condition.
   (B)   Any vehicle parked, stalled or incapable of moving under its own power
or which is left unattended on any snow route during a snow emergency condition
may be impounded by order of the Snow Removal Coordinator or his or her agents.
   (C)   The Snow Removal Coordinator, during any snow emergency condition,
after a snow route has been sufficiently cleared, may modify the foregoing
prohibition against parking in such manner as the Coordinator shall deem
reasonably safe.
   (D)   All agencies of the city, including, but not limited to the Police and
Fire Departments and the Street Department, shall cooperate with and assist the
Snow Removal Coordinator in the enforcement of the provisions of this title and
the impoundment of violating vehicles.
(1979 Code, § 75.03) (Ord. 3396, passed 5-24-1982)
Penalty, see § 75.99
§ 75.04 EMERGENCY SNOW REMOVAL ON RESIDENTIAL STREETS.
   When the Snow Removal Coordinator has declared a residential emergency, the
following traffic regulations shall be in effect:
   (A)   Parking shall be allowed on all snow routes as set forth in Chapter
78, Schedule VI.
   (B) Parking shall be banned weekdays between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:30
p.m. on all streets designated by the Snow Removal Coordinator. Notification
shall be given within a 24-hour period.
   (C) Any vehicle parked, stalled, incapable of moving under its own power, or
left unattended on any street in violation of this section shall be ticketed,
towed or impounded.
   (D)   The pushing of snow onto any city street or alley by any individual is
prohibited.
(1979 Code, § 75.04) (Ord. 3396, passed 5-24-1982)
Penalty, see § 75.99
§ 75.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating the provisions of this chapter may be fined not more
than $100 and costs and shall, in addition thereto, pay all charges or expenses
incurred in the impoundment of any vehicle in violation of the terms hereof.
(1979 Code, § 75.99) (Ord. 2694, passed 11-19-1973; Am. Ord. 3396, passed 5-24-
1982; Am. Ord. 4368, passed 7-8-1998)
CHAPTER 76: PARKING; PARKING METERS
Section
Parking Regulations
   
76.01   Definitions
   
76.02   Employment of persons
   
76.03   Board of Public Works authority
   
76.04   Seven-day parking zones
   
76.05   Maximum parking time
   
76.06   Occupancy of single space
   
76.07   Double parking prohibited

PARKING REGULATIONS
§ 76.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   OFF-STREET PUBLIC PARKING SPACE. A portion of an off-street public parking
zone so marked or lined as to define an area within which a single vehicle may
be parked.
   PUBLIC PARKING SPACE. A portion of a public street so marked or limited as
to define an area within which a single vehicle may be parked.
   VEHICLE. A device in, upon, or by which a person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a street or highway, except devices moved by human
power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks.
(1979 Code, § 76.01) (Ord. 2857, passed 4-19-1976; Am. Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-
2004)
§ 76.02 EMPLOYMENT OF PERSONS.
   The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city is authorized and empowered
to employ persons for the purposes of issuing citation tickets for violations
of all vehicle parking restrictions imposed by other ordinances of the city,
both as to parking on public streets and as to parking on off-street lots owned
or controlled by the city. All employees shall, by delivery of a copy of each
ticket, report all violations to the Traffic Division of the Police Department
of the city. No employee shall have any authority as or be deemed in any manner
to be a commissioned member of that department, nor shall any employee be
entitled to participate in or receive benefits under any pension plan or other
similar program administered for the benefit of commissioned members of the
Department. The Board of Public Works and Safety of the city is authorized and
empowered to employ as many persons, at rates of compensation and on other
terms and conditions as it determines, and to discharge any person, all in its
sole discretion, to the end that the purposes of this section may be properly
and effectively accomplished.
(1979 Code, § 76.02) (Ord. 2853, passed 4-19-1976)
Statutory reference:
   Local regulation of standing or parking of vehicles, see I.C. 9-21-1-3
§ 76.03 BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS AUTHORITY.
   (A)   The Board of Public Works, in its reasonable discretion, is authorized
to designate any public area(s) as no parking zone(s) to maintain or create
site triangles, maintain or create space for turning movements and for any
other purpose reasonably related to public safety. The Board of Public Works,
in its reasonable discretion, is further authorized to designate parking zone
(s) in public area(s) that prohibit van or truck parking, allow subcompact car
parking only, or contain any other restrictions or prohibitions that are
reasonably related to public safety.
   (B)   The Board of Public Works, in its reasonable discretion, is further
authorized to designate no parking zones in public areas during specific time
periods on specific days of the week in order to facilitate the orderly and
safe collection of refuse in the city.
   (C)   All no parking zones and/or any other zones described in this section
that have been designated by the Board of Public Works prior to the effective
date of Ord. 4846 are hereby ratified and confirmed.
(1979 Code, § 76.03) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004; Am. Ord. 4999, passed 11-20-
2006 )
§ 76.04 SEVEN-DAY PARKING ZONES.
   All on-street and off-street public parking areas in the city that are not
regulated in §
76.03, §
76.05 or Chapter 77, Schedules I–VII are hereby designated as 7-day parking
zones.
(1979 Code, § 76.04) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
§ 76.05 MAXIMUM PARKING TIME.
   It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any single 7-day public
parking space designated at §
76.04 for a period of time exceeding 7 days.
   (A)   It is a defense to
§ 76.04 and this section that when a vehicle occupies a public parking space
from seven to 30 days:
      (1)   The vehicle was parked for such period of time because the person
(s) with legal control of the possession of the vehicle by ownership, lease or
otherwise, was (were) physically absent from the city during all the subject
period of time that the vehicle remained in the public parking space; or
      (2)   The vehicle was parked for such period of time because the person
(s) with legal control of the possession of the vehicle by ownership, lease or
otherwise, because of physical health, was unable to assure the removal of the
vehicle within such period of time.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any single 24-
hour on-street public parking space or 24-hour off-street public parking space
designated in
Chapter 77, Schedules I and
II, for a period of time exceeding 24 hours.
   (C)   From 6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., it shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle
shall occupy any single 2- hour on-street public parking space or 2-hour off-
street public parking space designated in
Chapter 77, Schedules III and
IV, for a period of time exceeding 2 hours.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any single 15-
minute on-street public parking space designated in
Chapter 77, Schedule V, for a period of time exceeding 15 minutes.
   (E)   It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any single 2-hour
off-street public parking space designated in
Chapter 77, Schedule VI, for a period of time exceeding 2 hours.
   (F)   It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any parking space
designated as a no parking space pursuant to
Chapter 77, Schedule VII, or §
76.03. It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any parking space
in violation of no trucks, no vans, subcompact cars only, or other reasonable
restrictions established by the Board of Public Works pursuant to §
76.03. It shall be unlawful to, and no vehicle shall occupy any parking space
in violation of any temporary parking restriction implemented by a police
officer or the Traffic Engineer pursuant to §
76.11.
(1979 Code, § 76.05) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.06 OCCUPATION OF SINGLE SPACE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle so as to occupy any
portion of more than 1 parking space at one time, unless the size of the
vehicle exceeds the size of any single such parking space.
(1979 Code, § 76.06) (Ord. 2854, passed 4-19-1976; Am. Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-
2004)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.07 DOUBLE PARKING PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle or cause a vehicle to
be parked in the manner commonly known as double parking.
(1979 Code, § 76.07) (Ord. 2854, passed 4-19-1976; Am. Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-
2004)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.08 PARKING OF LARGE VEHICLES ON PUBLIC STREETS.
   (A)   No vehicle or combination of vehicles joined together, the overall
length of which is greater than 30 feet, and no vehicle or combination of
vehicles joined together, the width of which at the widest point is greater
than 8 feet, shall be parked upon the public streets or thoroughfares of the
city.
   (B)   For the purposes of determining vehicle length and width under this
section, any cargo or equipment loaded upon or attached to the vehicle shall be
considered part of the vehicle.
   (C)   Notwithstanding division (A) above, the vehicles may be parked upon
the public streets or thoroughfares of the city for the purpose of making a
local pickup or delivery; or for the purpose of removing them from the traveled
portion of the street, in the event the vehicle is disabled, until assistance
may be secured; or if the owner or operator of the vehicle has obtained a
permit from the Board of Public Works and Safety of the city, allowing the
vehicle to be so parked and the vehicle is parked according to the provisions
of the permit.
(1979 Code, § 76.08) (Ord. 2671, passed 8-20-1973)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.09 PARKING OF TRACTORS AND SEMITRAILERS.
   (A)   The parking of tractors or detached trailers or semi-trailers upon the
public streets or thoroughfares of the city is prohibited.
   (B)   Notwithstanding division (A) above, a tractor or detached trailer or
semitrailer may be parked upon the public streets or thoroughfares of the city
for the purpose of removing it from the traveled portion of the street, in the
event the vehicle, trailer, or semitrailer is disabled, until assistance may be
secured; or if the tractor, trailer or semitrailer is parked pursuant to and
within the provisions of a permit for the parking issued to the owner or
operator of the tractor, detached trailer or semitrailer by the Board of Public
Works and Safety of the city.
(1979 Code, § 76.09) (Ord. 2671, passed 8-20-1973)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.10 IMPOUNDMENT OF VEHICLES.
   (A)   This section does not apply to §§
76.04 and
76.05(A).
   (B)   In addition to any other penalty provided by this chapter for the
violation of any restriction as to parking of a vehicle, if any vehicle remains
parked in violation of any restriction as to parking of a vehicle in excess of
24 hours after the commencement of such violation, the city’s Police
Department, its representatives or agents, are authorized and empowered to
impound the vehicle and remove it from the illegal parking situation, with all
expenses of the impoundment and removal to be paid by the owner of the vehicle
before the vehicle may be released from the impoundment.
(1979 Code, § 76.10) (Ord. 2857, passed 4-19-1976; Am. Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-
2004)
§ 76.11 PARKING METERS PROHIBITED.
   No department or administrative agency of the city may install or use any
parking meter or similar device in any manner with regard to any parking space
in any on-street parking zone, without the passage of an ordinance that
establishes authority for such department or administrative agency to do so.
(1979 Code, § 76.11) (Ord. 2856, passed 4-19-1976; Am. Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-
2004)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.12 TEMPORARY PARKING SIGNS.
   A city police officer or a city’s Traffic Engineer, as designated by the
City Engineer, shall have the temporary authority to prohibit parking in any
location or to implement any other parking restrictions, and place signs
pursuant to such authority, to protect the immediate safety, health and welfare
of any citizen.
(1979 Code, § 76.12) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
§ 76.13 AUTHORITY TO ISSUE CITATIONS.
   City police officers, other city employees designated by the Police Chief,
Code Enforcement Officers designated by the city’s Building Commissioner and
Park Department employees designated by the city’s Parks Superintendent are
authorized and empowered to, on behalf of the city, issue tickets (citations)
and take any other lawful civil procedural action to prosecute violations of
this chapter or violations of any parking restrictions contained in any other
city ordinance(s).
(1979 Code, § 76.13) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
§ 76.14 ENFORCEMENT REMEDIES ARE NON-EXCLUSIVE.
   The enforcement remedies at §§
76.10 and
76.99 are not exclusive. Sections
76.10 and
76.99 do not preclude the enforcement of this chapter through the use of
remedies stated at I.C. 9-30-11 et seq. or at any other statutory provision or
valid law.
(1979 Code, § 76.14) (Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
§ 76.15 EXEMPTIONS.
   Notwithstanding the prohibitions in §§
76.01 through
76.14, the following persons shall be excepted from all parking restrictions
set forth in this subchapter and
Chapter 77, Schedules I through
VII, except for handicap parking violations, and shall be exempt from payment
of any fine for parking in violation of §§
76.01,
76.03 through
76.07 and
76.10 through
76.14:
   (A)   Any and all elected and appointed city officials, including but not
limited to, the members of the Council, Board of Public Works, Board of Public
Safety, the Mayor, City Clerk, City Court Judge and Director of Public Works,
while performing their official duties; and
   (B)   All employees of the city while operating a city vehicle within the
scope of their employment.
(Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
§ 76.16 REGULATION OF USE OF PARKING SPACES DESIGNATED FOR ELECTRIC VEHICLE
CHARGING.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to park any non-electric vehicle in a parking
space designated for electric vehicle charging.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for an electric vehicle to occupy a parking space
designated for electric vehicle charging unless the vehicle is engaged in the
charging process.
(Ord. 5934, passed 11-21-2022)
§ 76.17 FEE FOR USE OF CITY-OWNED ELECTRIC VEHICLE CHARGING STATIONS.
   (A)   Use of all city-owned electric vehicle charging stations is subject to
a flat hourly rate of $2 per hour.
   (B)   The city's electric vehicle charging stations located within the
Central Park parking lot and the Gause parking lot were obtained, in part,
through grant funding from the Indiana Department of Environmental Management
under VW Project Funding Agreement Number VWL2-027. As a condition of the
city's application for receipt of such grant funds, the city agreed to provide
the first 2 hours of charging at the grant-funded charging stations at no cost
to users for the first 2 years after its installation. The grant-funded
charging stations are to be installed by no later than December 31, 2022. Thus,
notwithstanding division (A), the city's electric vehicle charging stations
located within the Central Park parking lot and the Gause parking lot shall
provide the first two hours of charging at no cost through December 31, 2024.
   (C)   §§
76.03,
76.06,
76.10,
76.13, and
76.14 are non-exclusive and are all applicable to this section as if contained
herein.
(Ord. 5934, passed 11-21-2022)
PIERRE MORAN SHOPPING CENTER
§ 76.25 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   PIERRE MORAN SHOPPING CENTER. Real estate located in the city which is more
particularly described in Exhibit A of Ord. 4012, which is hereby incorporated
by reference as if fully set forth by this subchapter.
(1979 Code, § 76.25) (Ord. 4012, passed 11-19-1990)
§ 76.26 FIRE LANES ESTABLISHED.
   The Pierre Moran Shopping Center, by its agents, may establish fire lanes
adjacent to the buildings located on the property and erect signs identifying
those fire lanes at its own expense.
(1979 Code, § 76.26) (Ord. 4012, passed 11-19-1990)
§ 76.27 UNLAWFUL PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park a motor vehicle, except in
compliance with law or at the direction of a police officer, in a fire lane
established by Pierre Moran Shopping Center.
   (B)   No person shall park a motor vehicle on the property of Pierre Moran
Shopping Center at any time for a continuous period in excess of 24 hours. The
parking shall be prohibited on the property as described in Exhibit A of Ord.
4012, hereby incorporated by reference as if fully set forth by this
subchapter.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle so as to
occupy any portion of more than 1 parking space at one time, unless the size of
the vehicle exceeds the size of any single parking space. Vehicles shall be
parked in the parking spaces marked by painted lines on the parking pavement
and at no other place.
(1979 Code, § 76.27) (Ord. 4012, passed 11-19-1990)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.28 MAXIMUM PARKING TIME.
   Any motor vehicle parked in a fire lane or any vehicle parked in excess of
24 hours on the property described in Exhibit A of Ord. 4012, in violation of
this subchapter may be towed from the property by representatives or agents of
the city and caused to be stored at the expense of the owner or operator of the
vehicle.
(1979 Code, § 76.28) (Ord. 4012, passed 11-19-1990)
Penalty, see § 76.99

Brothers & Company, Inc., a Michigan Corporation, as managing agent for Concord

traffic at the Concord Mall, attached to Ord. 4067, passed 7-6-1992, is hereby

subchapter as the “contract”.

buildings located on the real estate and erect signs identifying those fire
lanes at its own expense.
(1979 Code, § 76.37) (Ord. 4067, passed 7-6-1992)
§ 76.48 UNLAWFUL PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall stop, stand or park a motor vehicle, except in
compliance with law or at the direction of a police officer, in a fire lane
established by Concord Mall on the real estate.
   (B)   No person shall park a motor vehicle on the real estate at any time
for a continuous period in excess of 24 hours. The parking shall be prohibited
on the real estate.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle so as to
occupy any portion of more than one parking space on the real estate at 1 time,
unless the size of the vehicle exceeds the size of any single parking space.
Vehicles shall be parked in the parking spaces marked by painted lines on the
parking pavement and at no other place.

or agents of the city and caused to be stored at the expense of the owner or
operator of the vehicle.
(1979 Code, § 76.39) (Ord. 4067, passed 7-6-1992)

   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definition shall apply

(1979 Code, § 76.46) (Ord. 4327, passed 12-4-1997)
§ 76.57 UNLAWFUL PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall park a motor vehicle at the parking area at any time
for any purpose other than to use A/G Mart as a customer, or to park as an
employee of A/G Mart for A/G Mart employment reasons.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle so as to
occupy any portion of more than 1 parking space at the parking area on the real
estate at 1 time, unless the size of the vehicle exceeds the size of any single
parking space. The vehicle shall be parked in the parking spaces marked by

   (C)   Any motor vehicle parked at A/G Mart for reasons other than customer

be stored at the expense of the owner/operator of the vehicle.
(1979 Code, § 76.47) (Ord. 4327, passed 12-4-1997)
Penalty, see § 76.99
§ 76.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person who violates any provision of §§
76.01 et seq. shall, upon adjudication or admission thereof, be punished as
stated in this division. Violations of this subchapter are deemed to be
continuing in nature and each coterminous period during which a vehicle remains
parked in violation of this subchapter constitutes a separate violation. The
registered owner of a vehicle parked in violation of §§
76.01 et seq. is in violation of this subchapter to the same extent as the
driver of the vehicle. Prosecution pursuant to this section can be made against
the registered owner and/or driver and the prosecution of one does not bar the
prosecution of the other.
      (1)   The schedule of penalties of violation of §§
76.01 et seq. shall be:
         (a)   For the first coterminous violation, the sum of $10 if paid in
full within 72 hours from the time of the issuance of the ticket (citation).
         (b)   The sum of $25 if paid in full after 72 hours from the time of
the issuance of the ticket (citation) until such time as the notice of
violation is sent to the City Attorney for prosecution.
         (c)   For each successive, coterminous violation, the sum of $25 until
such time as the notice of violation is sent to the City Attorney for
prosecution.
      (2)   Each day a violation continues shall be considered as a separate
offense. The city, in its discretion, may fine up to $50 for repeat violations
of this chapter. Violations herein may be prosecuted through the Ordinance
Violations Bureau or through any other legal means.
(Ord. 4846, passed 8-17-2004)
   (B)   Any person who violates any provision of §§
76.25 through
76.28 or §§
76.45 through
76.49 shall be punished as stated in this division.
      (1)   When a ticket or citation for a violation of this subchapter is
issued (except with respect to violations of handicapped parking space
restrictions), the owner or operator of the vehicle in violation shall pay the
sum of $5 as a fine to the city within 30 days after the date shown on the
ticket. Should the fine not be paid within 30 days, the fine shall increase to
the sum of $15.
      (2)   Violations of handicapped parking space restrictions shall result
in fines of $25 and should the fine not be paid within 30 days, the fine shall
increase to the sum of $50.
      (3)   After a complaint has been filed in a court of competent
jurisdiction against the registered owner of the vehicle charging the person
with a violation of one or more of the provisions of this chapter, that owner
shall, upon conviction, pay the court costs of the proceeding and be fined not
more than $50 for each violation. All fines shall, pursuant to the terms of the
contract as set out in Exhibit B of Ord. 4012 and the contract as set out in
Exhibit B of Ord. 4067, which is hereby incorporated by reference as if fully
set forth by this chapter, become the property of the city.
(1979 Code, § 76.99) (Ord. 4012, passed 11-19-1990; Am. Ord. 4067, passed 7-6-
1992)
Statutory reference:
   Shopping center’s right to regulate parking, see I.C. 9-21-18
